<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Included
in minimum rents is amortization of above and below market leases of $21.5&nbsp;million, $10.6&nbsp;million, $12.2&nbsp;million,
$11.0&nbsp;million and $9.2&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Included
in (gain) loss from early extinguishment of debt for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, is $95.3&nbsp;million from the repurchase and
retirement of $222.8&nbsp;million of the convertible senior notes ("Senior Notes") (See "Liquidity and Capital Resources").
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's Taxable REIT Subsidiaries ("TRSs") are subject to corporate level income taxes (See Note&nbsp;19&#151;Income Taxes of the Company's
Consolidated Financial Statements).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Discontinued
operations include the following: </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold Westbar on December&nbsp;16, 2004, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2004 to December&nbsp;16, 2004 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of
Westbar resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $6.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;5, 2005, the Company sold Arizona Lifestyle Galleries. The sale of this property resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $0.3&nbsp;million. The impact on the results of operations
for the period January&nbsp;1, 2005 to January&nbsp;5, 2005 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 have been reclassified to discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale&nbsp;101 and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to June&nbsp;9, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004
have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Scottsdale&nbsp;101 resulted in a gain on sale of asset, at the Company's pro rata share, of $25.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold Park Lane Mall on July&nbsp;13, 2006 and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to July&nbsp;13, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 have
been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Park Lane Mall resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $5.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold Greeley Mall and Holiday Village Mall in a combined sale on July&nbsp;27, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to July&nbsp;27, 2006 and the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of these properties resulted in a gain on sale of assets of $28.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold Great Falls Marketplace on August&nbsp;11, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to August&nbsp;11, 2006 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and
2004 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of Great Falls Marketplace resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $11.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold Citadel Mall, Crossroads Mall and Northwest Arkansas Mall in a combined sale on December&nbsp;29, 2006, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2006 to December&nbsp;29,
2006 and the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of these properties resulted in a gain on sale of assets of $132.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, the Company recorded an additional loss of $2.4&nbsp;million in 2007, related to the sale of properties in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;1, 2008, MACWH,&nbsp;LP, a subsidiary of the Operating Partnership, at the election of the holders, redeemed the 3.4&nbsp;million PCPUs in exchange for the 16.32% minority
interest in the Non-Rochester Properties, in exchange for the Company's ownership interest in the Rochester Properties. As a result of the Rochester Redemption, the Company recognized a
gain of $99.1&nbsp;million on the exchange. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company sold the fee simple and/or ground leasehold interests in three freestanding stores acquired from Mervyn's to Pacific Premier Retail Trust, one of its joint ventures, on December&nbsp;19,
2008, and the results for the period of January&nbsp;1, 2008 to December&nbsp;19, 2008 and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 have been classified as discontinued operations. The sale of
these interests resulted in a gain on sale of assets of $1.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Assumes
that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis. The Westcor
partnership units were converted into OP Units on July&nbsp;27, 2004, which were subsequently redeemed for common stock on October&nbsp;4, 2005. It also assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP
common and preferred units to the extent that they are dilutive to the EPS computation (See Note&nbsp;12&#151;Acquisitions in the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(6)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
the dilutive effect of share and unit-based compensation plans and convertible senior notes calculated using the treasury stock method
and the dilutive effect of all other dilutive securities calculated using the "if converted" method.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(7)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>"Minority
Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership and MACWH,&nbsp;LP not owned by the Company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(8)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
holder of the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock converted 560,000, 684,000, 1,338,860 and 1,044,271 shares to common shares on October&nbsp;18, 2007,
May&nbsp;6, 2008, May&nbsp;8, 2008 and September&nbsp;17, 2008, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, there was no Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock outstanding. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=41,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=335285,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DM15701A.;26',USER='GKIBBE',CD='26-FEB-2009;15:44' -->
<A NAME="page_dm15701_1_40"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(9)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company uses FFO in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO&#151;diluted as supplemental
measures for the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO
as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and
amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis.
FFO and FFO on a fully diluted basis are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and
amortization as the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully
diluted basis is one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by
GAAP, should not be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO as presented may not be comparable to
similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For disclosure of net income, the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure, for the periods presented and a
reconciliation of FFO and FFO&#151;diluted to net income, see "Item&nbsp;7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Funds from
Operations." </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
computation of FFO-diluted includes the effect of share and unit-based compensation plans and convertible senior notes calculated using the treasury stock method. It also
assumes the conversion of MACWH,&nbsp;LP common and preferred units and all other securities to the extent that they are dilutive to the FFO computation (See Note&nbsp;12&#151;Acquisitions
of the Company's Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements). On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. The Preferred Stock was
convertible on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock then outstanding was dilutive to FFO for all periods presented and was dilutive to net
income in 2006. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A> </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do15701_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do15701_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Management's Overview and Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management and leasing of regional and community
shopping centers located throughout the United States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, the Operating Partnership. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Operating Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 72 regional shopping centers and 20 community shopping centers totaling approximately 76&nbsp;million square
feet of GLA. These 92 regional and community
shopping centers are referred to hereinafter as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed REIT and conducts all
of its operations through the Operating Partnership and the Company's Management Companies. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006. It compares the results
of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 to the results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. Also included is a comparison of the
results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the results of operations and cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. This information should be
read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes thereto. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Acquisitions and Dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The financial statements reflect the following acquisitions, dispositions and changes in ownership subsequent to the occurrence of each
transaction. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
February&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Valley River Center, a 915,656 square foot super-regional mall in Eugene, Oregon. The total purchase price was $187.5&nbsp;million and
concurrent with the acquisition, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million ten-year loan on the property. The balance of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the
Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;9, 2006, the Company sold Scottsdale 101, a 564,000 square foot center in Phoenix, Arizona. The sale price was $117.6&nbsp;million from which $56.0&nbsp;million was
used to payoff the mortgage on the property. The Company's share of the realized gain was $25.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;13, 2006, the Company sold Park Lane Mall, a 370,000 square foot center in Reno, Nevada, for $20&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of $5.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;26, 2006, the Company purchased 11 department stores located in 10 of its Centers from Federated Department Stores,&nbsp;Inc. for approximately $100.0&nbsp;million.
The purchase price consisted of a $93.0&nbsp;million cash payment at closing and a $7.0&nbsp;million cash payment in 2007, in connection with development work by Federated at the Company's
development properties. The Company's share of the purchase price was $81.0&nbsp;million and was funded in part from the proceeds of sales of Park Lane Mall, Greeley Mall, Holiday Village Mall and
Great Falls Marketplace, and from borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The balance of the purchase price was paid by the Company's joint venture partners. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;27, 2006, the Company sold Holiday Village Mall, a 498,000 square foot center in Great Falls, Montana, and Greeley Mall, a 564,000 square foot center in Greeley, Colorado,
in a combined sale for $86.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $28.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
August&nbsp;11, 2006, the Company sold Great Falls Marketplace, a 215,000 square foot community center in Great Falls, Montana, for $27.5&nbsp;million resulting in a gain of
$11.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=43,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=487326,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company acquired Deptford Mall, a two-level&nbsp;1.0&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Deptford, New Jersey. The total
purchase price of $240.1&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. On December&nbsp;7, 2006, the Company placed a $100.0&nbsp;million
six-year loan bearing interest at a fixed rate of 5.44% on the property. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;29, 2006, the Company sold Citadel Mall, a 1,095,000 square foot center in Colorado Springs, Colorado, Crossroads Mall, a 1,268,000 square foot center in Oklahoma
City, Oklahoma, and Northwest Arkansas Mall, a 820,000 square foot center in Fayetteville, Arkansas, in a combined sale for $373.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain of $132.7&nbsp;million. The net
proceeds were used to pay down the Company's line of credit and pay off the Company's $75.0&nbsp;million loan on Paradise Valley Mall. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Valley
River Center and Deptford Mall are referred to herein as the "2006 Acquisition Centers." </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
September&nbsp;5, 2007, the Company purchased the remaining 50% outside ownership interest in Hilton Village, a 96,985 square foot specialty center in Scottsdale, Arizona. The total
purchase price of $13.5&nbsp;million was funded by cash, borrowings under the Company's line of credit and the assumption of a mortgage note payable. The Center was previously accounted for under
the equity method as an investment in unconsolidated joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;17, 2007, the Company purchased a portfolio of ground leasehold interest and/or fee interests in 39 freestanding Mervyn's stores located in the Southwest United
States. The purchase price of $400.2&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hilton
Village and the interest in the 39 freestanding Mervyn's freestanding stores are referred herein as the "2007 Acquisition Properties." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;1, 2008, a subsidiary of the Operating Partnership, at the election of the holders, redeemed its 3.4&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A participating convertible preferred
units ("PCPUs"). As a result of the redemption, the Company received the 16.32% minority interest in the portion of the Wilmorite portfolio acquired on April&nbsp;25, 2005 that included Danbury Fair
Mall, Freehold Raceway Mall, Great Northern Mall, Rotterdam Square, Shoppingtown Mall, Towne Mall, Tysons Corner Center and Wilton Mall, collectively, referred to as the "Non-Rochester
Properties," for total consideration of $224.4&nbsp;million, in exchange for the Company's ownership interest in the portion of the Wilmorite portfolio that consisted of Eastview Mall, Eastview
Commons, Greece Ridge Center, Marketplace Mall and Pittsford Plaza, collectively referred to as the "Rochester Properties." Included in the redemption consideration was the assumption of the remaining
16.32% interest in the indebtedness of the Non-Rochester Properties, which had an estimated fair value of $106.0&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company also received additional
consideration of $11.8&nbsp;million, in the form of a note, for certain working capital adjustments, extraordinary capital expenditures, leasing commissions, tenant allowances, and decreases in
indebtedness during the Company's period of ownership of the Rochester Properties. The Company recognized a gain of $99.1&nbsp;million on the exchange. This exchange is referred to herein as the
"Rochester Redemption." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;10, 2008, the Company, in a 50/50 joint venture, acquired The Shops at North Bridge, a 680,933 square foot urban shopping center in Chicago, Illinois, for a total
purchase price of $515.0&nbsp;million. The Company's share of the purchase price was funded by the assumption of a pro rata share of the $205.0&nbsp;million fixed rate mortgage on the Center and
by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company purchased a ground leasehold interest in a freestanding Mervyn's store located in Hayward, California. The purchase price of $13.2&nbsp;million
was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=44,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=283313,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
February&nbsp;29, 2008, the Company purchased a fee simple interest in a freestanding Mervyn's store located in Monrovia, California. The purchase price of $19.3&nbsp;million was
funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;20, 2008, the Company purchased a fee simple interest in a 161,350 square foot Boscov's department store at Deptford Mall in Deptford, New Jersey. The total purchase price
of $23.5&nbsp;million
was funded by the assumption of the existing $15.2&nbsp;million mortgage note on the property and by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Boscov's store and the Mervyn's stores acquired in 2008 are referred to herein as the "2008 Acquisition Properties." </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;11, 2008, the Company became a 50% owner in a joint venture that acquired One Scottsdale, which plans to develop a luxury retail and mixed-use property in
Scottsdale, Arizona. The Company's share of the purchase price was $52.5&nbsp;million, which was funded by borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;19, 2008, the Company sold a fee and/or ground leasehold interest in three freestanding Mervyn's department stores to Pacific Premier Retail Trust, one of the
Company's joint ventures, for $43.4&nbsp;million, resulting in a gain on sale of assets of $1.5&nbsp;million. The Company's pro rata share of the proceeds were used to pay down the Company's line
of credit. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Mervyn's:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2008, Mervyn's filed for bankruptcy protection and announced in October its plans to liquidate all merchandise, auction its
store leases and wind down its business. The Company has 45 former Mervyn's stores in its portfolio. The Company owns the ground leasehold and/or fee simple interest in 44 of those stores and the
remaining store is owned by a third party but is located at one of the Centers. In connection with the acquisition of the Mervyn's portfolio (See Note&nbsp;12-Acquisitions of the
Company's Consolidated Financial Statements) and applying Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;141, the Company recorded intangible assets of $110.7&nbsp;million and
intangible liabilities of $59.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
September&nbsp;2008, the Company recorded a write-down of $5.2&nbsp;million due to the anticipated rejection of six of the Company's leases by Mervyn's. In addition,
the Company terminated its former plan to sell the 29 Mervyn's stores located at shopping centers not owned or managed by the Company. (See Note&nbsp;13&#151;Discontinued Operations of the
Company's Consolidated Financial Statements). The Company's decision was based on current conditions in the credit market and the assumption that a better return could be obtained by holding and
operating the assets. As result of the change in plans to sell, the Company recorded a loss of $5.3&nbsp;million in order to adjust the carrying value of these assets for depreciation expense that
otherwise would have been recognized had these assets been continuously classified as held and used. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2008, Kohl's and Forever 21 assumed a total of 23 of the Mervyn's leases and the remaining 22 leases were rejected by Mervyn's under the bankruptcy laws. As a result, the
Company wrote-off the unamortized intangible assets and liabilities related to the rejected and unassumed leases in December 2008. The Company wrote-off $27.7&nbsp;million of
unamortized intangible assets related to lease in place values, leasing commissions and legal costs to depreciation and amortization. Unamortized intangible assets of $14.9&nbsp;million relating to
above market leases and unamortized intangible liabilities of $24.5&nbsp;million relating to below market leases were written-off to minimum rents. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Redevelopments and Developments:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Construction continues on Santa Monica Place, a regional shopping center under development in Santa Monica, California. In September,
the Company announced that Bloomingdale's will join </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=45,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=846961,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_44"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Nordstrom.
Bloomingdale's will open the first of the store's SoHo concept outside of Manhattan. In addition, the Company has announced deals with 11 retailers and restaurants slated to join the new
Santa Monica Place&#151;Ed Hardy, Arthur, R.O.C. Republic of Couture, Ilori, Love Culture, Michael Brandon, Shuz, restaurants La Sandia, Zengo and Pizza Antica, and gallery Artevo. These 11
strong brands join previously announced restaurants XINO and Osumo Sushi and fashion retailers Kitson LA, BCBG Max Azria, Coach, Lacoste, Joe's Jeans and True Religion, all of which are slated to open
in 2010 alongside Bloomingdale's SoHo concept and Nordstrom. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
Scottsdale Fashion Square, construction on an approximately 160,000 square foot expansion continues on schedule toward a Fall 2009 opening. The expansion will be anchored by a 60,000
square foot Barneys New York. In addition, recently signed fashion retailer Ed Hardy, French luxury homewear retailer Arthur and Forever 21 will join previously announced True Religion and restaurants
Marcella's and Modern Steak, in the new wing. Recent additions to the Center's interior merchandise mix include Cartier and Bvlgari. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also
during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company wrote off $8.7&nbsp;million of development costs on development projects the Company has determined it will not
pursue. In addition, the Company recorded an $18.8&nbsp;million impairment charge to reduce its pro rata share of the carrying value of land held for development at a consolidated joint venture. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Inflation:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the last three years, inflation has not had a significant impact on the Company because of a relatively low inflation rate. Most of
the leases at the Centers have rent adjustments periodically through the lease term. These rent increases are either in fixed increments or based on using an annual multiple of increases in the
Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). In addition, about 6%-13% of the leases expire each year, which enables the Company to replace existing leases with new leases at higher base rents if the
rents of the existing leases are below the then existing market rate. Additionally, historically the majority of the leases required the tenants to pay their pro rata share of operating expenses. In
January 2005, the Company began entering into leases that require tenants to pay a stated amount for operating expenses, generally excluding property taxes, regardless of the expenses actually
incurred at any Center. This change shifts the burden of cost control to the Company. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Seasonality:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The shopping center industry is seasonal in nature, particularly in the fourth quarter during the holiday season when retailer
occupancy and retail sales are typically at their highest levels. In addition, shopping malls achieve a substantial portion of their specialty (temporary retailer) rents during the holiday season and
the majority of percentage rent is recognized in the fourth quarter. As a result of the above, earnings are generally higher in the fourth quarter. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Critical Accounting Policies  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP") in the United States of
America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the
financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgments on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectible
accounts, impairment of long-lived assets, the allocation of purchase price between tangible and intangible assets, and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant
accounting policies are described </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=46,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=76412,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_45"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>in
more detail in Note&nbsp;2&#151;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies to the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following policies are deemed to be critical. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenue Recognition  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the related lease. The difference between
the amount of rent due in a year and the amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight line rent adjustment." Currently, 53% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions
for CPI rent increases periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in
revenue recognition that more closely matches the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized when the
tenants' specified sales targets have been met. Estimated recoveries from certain tenants for their pro rata share of real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are
recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are incurred. Other tenants pay a fixed rate and these tenant recoveries' revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over
the term of the related leases. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Property  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company capitalizes costs incurred in redevelopment and development of properties in accordance with Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;34 "Capitalization of Interest Cost" and SFAS No.&nbsp;67 "Accounting for Costs and the Initial Rental Operations of Real Estate Properties." The costs of
land and buildings under development include specifically identifiable costs. The capitalized costs include pre-construction costs essential to the development of the property, development
costs, construction costs, interest costs, real estate taxes, salaries and related costs and other costs incurred during the period of development. Capitalized costs are allocated to the specific
components of a project that are benefited. The Company considers a construction project as completed and held available for occupancy and ceases capitalization of costs when the areas under
development have been substantially completed. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance
and repair expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc., are
capitalized and depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="322" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="45" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Accounting for Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for all acquisitions in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations." The Company first determines
the value of the land and buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company then assigns a fair value to any debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the purchase price is allocated to
tenant improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements represent the tangible assets associated with the existing leases valued on a fair market value basis at the
acquisition date prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under real estate investments and are depreciated over the remaining lease terms.
Identifiable intangible assets and liabilities relate to the value of in-place </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=47,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=225018,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_46"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>operating
leases which come in three forms: (i)&nbsp;leasing commissions and legal costs, which represent the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as
lease commissions paid under terms generally experienced in the Company's markets; (ii)&nbsp;value of in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs
incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed vacant" property to the occupancy level when purchased; and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which
represents the difference between the contractual rents and market rents at the time of the acquisition, discounted for tenant credit risks. Leasing commissions and legal costs are recorded in
deferred charges and other assets and are amortized over the remaining lease terms. The value of in-place leases are recorded in deferred charges and other assets and amortized over the
remaining lease terms plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market leases are classified in deferred charges and other assets or in other accrued liabilities, depending on
whether the contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is amortized to minimum rents over the remaining terms of the leases. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When
the Company acquires a real estate property, the Company allocates the purchase price to the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates
and assumptions. These estimates and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property
acquisitions. These allocations also impact depreciation expense and gains or losses recorded on future sales of properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Asset Impairment  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company assesses whether there has been impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as
expected future operating income, trends and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenant's ability to perform their duties and
pay rent under the terms of the leases. The Company may recognize impairment losses if the cash flows are not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference
between the carrying value and the fair value of a center. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Fair Value of Financial Instruments:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;1, 2008, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;157, "Fair Value Measurements." SFAS No.&nbsp;157 defines fair value,
establishes a framework for measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The fair value hierarchy distinguishes between market participant assumptions based on market
data obtained from sources independent of the reporting entity and the reporting entity's own assumptions about market participant assumptions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Level&nbsp;1
inputs utilize quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company has the ability to access. Level&nbsp;2 inputs are inputs other than
quoted prices included in Level&nbsp;1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly. Level&nbsp;2 inputs may include quoted prices for similar assets and
liabilities in active markets, as well as inputs that are observable for the asset or liability (other than quoted prices), such as interest rates, foreign exchange rates, and yield curves that are
observable at commonly quoted intervals. Level&nbsp;3 inputs are unobservable inputs for the asset or liability, which are typically based on an entity's own assumptions, as there is little, if any,
related market activity. In instances where the determination of the fair value measurement is based on inputs from different levels of the fair value hierarchy, the level in the fair value hierarchy
within which the entire fair value measurement falls is based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety. The Company's assessment of the significance
of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment, and considers factors specific to the asset or liability. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=48,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=396822,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_47"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company calculates the fair value of financial instruments and includes this additional information in the notes to consolidated financial statements when the fair value is different
than the carrying value of those financial instruments. When the fair value reasonably approximates the carrying value, no additional disclosure is made. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Deferred Charges  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the
straight-line method. Costs relating to financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method,
which approximates the effective interest method. In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of the renewal term. Leasing commissions and legal
costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over the individual remaining lease years. The ranges of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->

<TD WIDTH="131" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">

</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred financing costs</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>In-place lease values</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Remaining lease term plus an estimate for renewal</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Leasing commissions and legal costs</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Recent Accounting Pronouncements Not Yet Adopted  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2007, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued SFAS No.&nbsp;141(R), Business Combinations, and
SFAS No.&nbsp;160, Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated Financial Statements&#151;An Amendment of ARB No.&nbsp;51. SFAS No.&nbsp;141(R) requires an acquiring entity to recognize
acquired assets and assumed liabilities in a transaction at fair value as of the acquisition date and changes the accounting treatment for certain items, including acquisition costs, which will be
required to be expensed as incurred. SFAS No.&nbsp;160 requires that noncontrolling interests be presented as a component of consolidated stockholders' equity and eliminates "minority interest
accounting" such that the amount of net income attributable to the noncontrolling interests will be presented as part of consolidated net income on the consolidated statements of operations. SFAS
No.&nbsp;141(R) and SFAS No.&nbsp;160 require concurrent adoption and are to be applied prospectively for the first annual reporting period beginning on or after December&nbsp;15, 2008. Early
adoption of either standard is prohibited. The Company believes that these statements will not have a material impact on its consolidated results of operations or cash flows. However, the Company is
currently evaluating whether the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;160 could have a material impact on the consolidated balance sheets and consolidated statements of stockholders' equity. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2008, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position APB 14-1, Accounting for Convertible Debt Instruments That May Be Settled Upon Conversion (Including Partial Cash
Settlement) ("FSP APB 14-1"). This new standard requires the initial proceeds from convertible debt that may be settled in cash to be bifurcated between a liability component and an equity
component. The objective of the guidance is to require the liability and equity components of convertible debt to be separately accounted for in a manner such that the interest expense recorded on the
convertible debt would not equal the contractual rate of interest on the convertible debt, but instead would be recorded at a rate that would reflect the issuer's conventional
non-convertible debt borrowing rate at the date of issuance. This is accomplished through the creation of a discount on the debt that would be accreted using the effective interest method
as additional non-cash interest expense over the period the debt is expected to remain outstanding. The Company is required to adopt FSP APB 14-1 on January&nbsp;1, 2009.
This FSP will be applied retrospectively to all periods presented. The Company currently expects that FSP APB </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=49,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=877690,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_48"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>14-1
will have a material impact on the accounting for the convertible senior notes ("Senior Notes") and the Company's consolidated balance sheets and results of operations. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2008, the FASB issued Staff Position EITF No.&nbsp;03-6-1, "Determining Whether Instruments Granted in Share-Based Payment Transactions Are
Participating Securities." FSP EITF No.&nbsp;03-6-1 will be applied retrospectively to all the periods presented for the fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15,
2008. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adoption of FSP EITF No.&nbsp;03-6-1 on its results of operations and financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2008, the FASB ratified EITF Issue No.&nbsp;07-5, Determining Whether an Instrument (or Embedded Feature) Is Indexed to an Entity's Own Stock.
Paragraph&nbsp;11(a) of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, Accounting for Derivatives and Hedging Activities, specifies that a contract that would otherwise meet the definition of a derivative but is both
(a)&nbsp;indexed to the Company's own stock and (b)&nbsp;classified in stockholders' equity in the statement of financial position would not be considered a derivative financial instrument. EITF
Issue No.&nbsp;07-5 provides a new two-step model to be applied in determining whether a financial instrument or an embedded feature is indexed to an issuer's own stock and
thus able to qualify for the SFAS No.&nbsp;133 paragraph&nbsp;11(a) scope exception. EITF Issue No.&nbsp;07-5 will be effective for the first annual reporting period beginning after
December&nbsp;15, 2008, and early adoption is prohibited. Management is currently evaluating whether the adoption of EITF Issue No.&nbsp;07-5 will have an impact on the accounting for
the Senior Notes and related capped call option transactions. In the event that management determines that the adoption of EITF Issue No.&nbsp;07-05 impacts the accounting for the Senior
Notes, management's current conclusion regarding the impact of FSP APB-14-1 could change. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Results of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Many of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the transactions described above including the
2008 Acquisition Properties, the 2007 Acquisition Properties, the 2006 Acquisition Centers and the Redevelopment Centers. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 to the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the "Same Centers" include all consolidated Centers, excluding the 2008 Acquisition Properties, the 2007 Acquisition Properties and the Redevelopment Centers. For the
comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Same Centers include all consolidated Centers, excluding the 2007 Acquisition Properties, the 2006
Acquisition Centers and the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, "Redevelopment Centers" include The Oaks, Northgate Mall, Santa Monica Place,
Shoppingtown Mall, Westside Pavilion, The Marketplace at Flagstaff, SanTan Village Regional Center and Promenade at Casa Grande. For the comparison of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 to the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, "Redevelopment Centers" include The Oaks, Twenty Ninth Street, Santa Monica Place, Westside Pavilion, The Marketplace at Flagstaff Mall, SanTan Village Regional
Center and Promenade at Casa Grande. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unconsolidated
joint ventures are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The Company's pro rata share of the results from these Centers is reflected in the Consolidated
Statements of Operations as equity in income from unconsolidated joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenues:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minimum and percentage rents (collectively referred to as "rental revenue") increased by $61.7&nbsp;million, or 12.3%, from 2007 to
2008. The increase in rental revenue is attributed to an increase of $42.1&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties, $13.9&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=50,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=719939,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DO15701A.;31',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:49' -->
<A NAME="page_do15701_1_49"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$3.8&nbsp;million
from the 2008 Acquisition Properties and $1.9&nbsp;million from the Same Centers. The increase in the revenues from the Same Centers is primarily due to rent escalations and
lease renewals at higher rents, which was offset by decreases in lease termination income, amortization of straight-line rents and amortization of above and below market leases. The
increase in the revenues from the Same Centers was also offset by a decrease of $6.3&nbsp;million in percentage rents due to a decrease in retail sales. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rental
revenue includes the amortization of above and below market leases, the amortization of straight-line rents and lease termination income. The amortization of above and
below market leases increased from $10.6&nbsp;million in 2007 to $21.5&nbsp;million in 2008. The amortization of straight-lined rents decreased from $6.9&nbsp;million in 2007 to
$5.7&nbsp;million in 2008. Lease termination income increased from $9.7&nbsp;million in 2007 to $9.9&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase in above and below market leases is primarily due to the
early termination of Mervyn's leases in 2008 (See "Management's Overview and Summary&#151;Mervyn's."). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tenant
recoveries increased $21.4&nbsp;million, or 8.7%, from 2007 to 2008. The increase in tenant recoveries is attributed to an increase of $9.4&nbsp;million from the Same Centers,
$6.3&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties, $4.7 from the Redevelopment Centers and $1.0&nbsp;million from the 2008 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
Companies' revenues increased by $1.0&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008, primarily due to increased management fees received from the Joint Venture Centers, additional third
party management contracts and increased development fees from joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Shopping Center and Operating Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shopping center and operating expenses increased $30.3&nbsp;million, or 11.8%, from 2007 to 2008. Approximately $13.6&nbsp;million
of the increase in shopping center and operating expenses is from the Same Centers, $11.3&nbsp;million is from the 2007 Acquisition Properties, $5.0&nbsp;million is from the Redevelopment Centers
and $1.2&nbsp;million is from the 2008 Acquisition Properties. The increase in Same Centers is primarily due to an increase in recoverable utility expenses and property taxes and a
$2.0&nbsp;million increase in bad debt expense. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Operating Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' operating expenses increased $3.3&nbsp;million in 2007 to 2008, in part as a result of the additional costs of
managing the Joint Venture Centers and third party managed properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> REIT General and Administrative Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;REIT general and administrative expenses decreased by $0.1&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008. The decrease is primarily due to a
decrease in share and unit-based compensation expense in 2008. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Depreciation and Amortization:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $65.3&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008. The increase in depreciation and amortization is
primarily attributed to an increase of $42.1&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties, $12.0&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, $7.3&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and
$3.7&nbsp;million from the 2008 Acquisition Properties. Included in the increase of depreciation and amortization of 2007 Acquisition Properties is the write-off of $32.9&nbsp;million
of intangible assets as a result of the early termination of Mervyn's leases (See "Management's Overview and Summary&#151;Mervyn's.") </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Expense:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense increased $31.2&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008. The increase in interest expense was primarily attributed to an
increase of $17.9&nbsp;million from borrowings under the Company's line of credit, $9.3&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, $5.4&nbsp;million from the Senior Notes issued on
March&nbsp;16, 2007 and $4.7&nbsp;million from the Same Centers. The increase in interest expense was offset in part by a decrease of $3.8&nbsp;million from term loans. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in interest expense on the Company's line of credit was due to an increase in average outstanding borrowings during 2008, in part, because of the
purchase of The Shops at North Bridge, the 2007 Acquisition Properties and the 2008 Acquisition Properties and the repurchase and retirement of Senior Notes in 2008, which is offset in part by lower
LIBOR rates and spreads. The decrease in interest on term loans was due to the repayment of the $250&nbsp;million loan in 2007. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
above interest expense items are net of capitalized interest, which increased from $32.0&nbsp;million in 2007 to $33.3&nbsp;million in 2008 due to an increase in redevelopment
activity in 2008. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> (Gain) Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a gain of $95.3&nbsp;million on the early extinguishment of $222.8&nbsp;million of the Senior Notes in 2008.
In 2007, the Company recorded a $0.9&nbsp;million loss from the early extinguishment of the $250&nbsp;million term loan (See "Liquidity and Capital Resources".) </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Equity in Income of Unconsolidated Joint Ventures:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures increased $12.4&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008. The increase in equity in
income of unconsolidated joint ventures is due in part to commission income of $6.5&nbsp;million earned in 2008 from a joint venture, $3.6&nbsp;million relating to the acquisition of The Shops at
North Bridge in 2008, and $2.0&nbsp;million relating to a loss on the sale of assets in the SDG Macerich Properties,&nbsp;L.P. joint venture in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> (Loss) Gain on Sale or Write-down of Assets:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a loss on sale or write down of assets of $31.8&nbsp;million in 2008 relating to an $8.7&nbsp;million
write-off of development costs on projects the Company has determined not to pursue, a $19.2&nbsp;million impairment charge to reduce the carrying value of land held for development and
a $5.3&nbsp;million adjustment to reduce the carrying value of Mervyn's stores that the Company had previously classified as held for sale (See "Management's Overview and
Summary&#151;Mervyn's.") The gain on sale or write-down of assets in 2007 of $12.1&nbsp;million is primarily related to gain on sales of land. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Discontinued Operations:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income from discontinued operations increased $98.8&nbsp;million from 2007 to 2008. The increase is primarily due to the
$99.1&nbsp;million gain from the Rochester Redemption in 2008. See "Management's Overview and Summary&#151;Acquisitions and Dispositions." As a result of the Rochester Redemption, the Company
classified the results of operations for these properties to discontinued operations for all periods presented. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Minority Interest in the Operating Partnership:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The minority interest in the Operating Partnership represents the 14.4% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership not
owned by the Company during 2008 compared to the 15.0% not owned by the Company during 2007. The decrease in minority interest is primarily attributed to the conversion of 3,067,131 preferred shares
into common shares in 2008 (See
Note&nbsp;22&#151;Cumulative Convertible Redeemable Preferred Stock of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements) and the repurchase of 807,000 shares in 2007 (See
Note&nbsp;21&#151;Stock Repurchase Program of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=52,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=847792,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DQ15701A.;34',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dq15701_1_51"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Funds From Operations:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Primarily as a result of the factors mentioned above, "FFO"&#151;diluted increased 19.2% from $407.9&nbsp;million in 2007 to
$486.4&nbsp;million in 2008. For disclosure of net income, the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure, for the periods and a reconciliation of FFO and FFO&#151;diluted to net income
available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Operating Activities:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow from operations decreased from $326.1&nbsp;million in 2007 to $251.9&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease was primarily due
to changes in assets and liabilities in 2007 compared to 2008, an increase in distributions of income from unconsolidated joint ventures and due to the results at the Centers as discussed above. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Investing Activities:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in investing activities decreased from $865.3&nbsp;million in 2007 to $559.0&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease in cash
used in investing activities was primarily due to a decrease in capital expenditures of $507.7&nbsp;million and acquisition deposits of $51.9&nbsp;million offset by a decrease in distributions
from unconsolidated joint ventures of $132.5&nbsp;million and an increase in contributions to unconsolidated joint ventures. The decrease in capital expenditures is primarily due to the purchase of
the Mervyn's portfolio for $400.2&nbsp;million in 2007. The decrease in acquisition deposits and the increase in contributions to unconsolidated joint ventures is primarily due to the Company's
purchase of a pro
rata share of The Shops at North Bridge for $155.0&nbsp;million in 2008 (See "Management's Overview and Summary&#151;Acquisitions and Dispositions.") The decrease in distributions from
unconsolidated joint ventures is due to the receipt of the Company's pro rata share of loan proceeds from the refinance transactions at various unconsolidated joint ventures in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Financing Activities:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flow provided by financing activities decreased from $355.1&nbsp;million in 2007 to $288.3&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease
in cash provided by financing activities was primarily attributed to the issuance of $950&nbsp;million of Senior Notes in 2007, the repurchase of $222.8&nbsp;million of Senior Notes in 2008 (see
"Liquidity and Capital Resources") and the purchase of the Capped Calls in connection with the issuance of the Senior Notes in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revenues:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rental revenue increased by $39.7&nbsp;million, or 8.6%, from 2006 to 2007. The increase in rental revenue is attributed to an
increase of $17.9&nbsp;million from the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $13.8&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers, $6.7&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and $1.2&nbsp;million from the 2007
Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amortization of above and below market leases, which is recorded in rental revenue, decreased to $10.6&nbsp;million in 2007 from $12.2&nbsp;million in 2006. The decrease in
amortization is primarily due to leases which were terminated in 2006. The amortization of straight-lined rents, included in rental revenue, was $6.9&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to
$4.7&nbsp;million in 2006. Lease termination income, which is included in rental revenue, decreased to $9.8&nbsp;million in 2007 from $13.2&nbsp;million in 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tenant
recoveries increased $17.9&nbsp;million, or 7.9%, from 2006 to 2007. The increase in tenant recoveries is attributed to an increase of $11.0&nbsp;million from the 2006
Acquisition Centers, $4.3&nbsp;million from the
Redevelopment Centers, $2.4&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and $0.2&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=53,EFW="2189901",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=550034,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK105:[08ZDX1.08ZDX15701]DQ15701A.;34',USER='KSOLTER',CD='26-FEB-2009;19:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dq15701_1_52"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg15701a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
Companies' revenues increased by $8.3&nbsp;million from 2006 to 2007, primarily due to increased management fees received from the Joint Venture Centers, additional third
party management contracts and increased development fees from joint ventures. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Shopping Center and Operating Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Shopping center and operating expenses increased $23.1&nbsp;million, or 9.9%, from 2006 to 2007. Approximately $9.6&nbsp;million of
the increase in shopping center and operating expenses is from the 2006 Acquisition Centers, $6.8&nbsp;million is from the Redevelopment Centers, $6.1&nbsp;million is from the Same Centers and
$0.5&nbsp;million is from the 2007 Acquisition Properties. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Management Companies' Operating Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Companies' operating expenses increased to $73.8&nbsp;million in 2007 from $56.7&nbsp;million in 2006, in part as a
result of the additional costs of managing the Joint Venture Centers and third party managed properties, higher compensation expense due to increased staffing and higher professional fees. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> REIT General and Administrative Expenses:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;REIT general and administrative expenses increased by $3.1&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006, primarily due to increased share and
unit-based compensation expense in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Depreciation and Amortization:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization increased $15.7&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006. The increase in depreciation and amortization is
primarily attributed to an increase of $10.5&nbsp;million at the Redevelopment Centers, $10.4&nbsp;million from the 2006 Acquisition Centers and $0.1&nbsp;million from the 2007 Acquisition
Properties. This increase is offset in part by a decrease of $1.8&nbsp;million from the Same Centers. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest Expense:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense decreased $10.6&nbsp;million in 2007 from 2006. The decrease in interest expense was primarily attributed to a
decrease of $17.2&nbsp;million from term loans, $16.1&nbsp;million from the line of credit, $8.1&nbsp;million from the Same Centers and $2.7&nbsp;million from the Redevelopment Centers. The
decrease in interest expense was offset in part by an increase of $27.3&nbsp;million from the $950.0&nbsp;million Senior Notes issued on March&nbsp;16, 2007 and $6.6&nbsp;million from the 2006
Acquisition Centers. The decrease in interest on term loans was due to the repayment of the $250&nbsp;million loan in 2007 and the repayment of the $619&nbsp;million term loan in 2006. The
decrease in interest on the line of credit was due to: (i)&nbsp;a decrease in average outstanding borrowings during 2007, in part, because of the issuance of the Senior Notes, (ii)&nbsp;a decrease
in interest rates because of the $400&nbsp;million swap and (iii)&nbsp;lower LIBOR rates and spreads. The decrease in interest from the Same Centers is due to: (i)&nbsp;the repayment of the
$75.0&nbsp;million loan on Paradise Valley Mall in January 2007, (ii)&nbsp;an increase in capitalized interest and (iii)&nbsp;a decrease in LIBOR rates on floating rate mortgages payable. The
above interest expense items are net of capitalized interest, which increased to $32.0&nbsp;million in 2007 from $14.9&nbsp;million in 2006 due to an increase in redevelopment activity in 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt:  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a $0.9&nbsp;million loss from the early extinguishment of the $250&nbsp;million term loan in 2007. In 2006,
the Company recorded a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $1.8&nbsp;million related to the pay off of the $619&nbsp;million term loan. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
